page.title: 01BARTON _ UPON _ HUMBER
page.content: Barton could be described as a handsome old market town,noted today as the place where the A15 becomes airborne over the Humber bridge. The town is full of tree-lined streets and has many red bricked Georgian houses as well as two fine old churches _St.Peters and St.Marys In the South of the town is a fine old Georgian house _ Baysgarth house in which is a small museum. Before the bridge,Barton was once famous for its large claypits from which "Humber Warp" clay was once dug for use in brick and tile making. In the original Domesday book Barton was already a town of some significance in the county and today it is twinned with the town of Feyzin in France.
